intro: Leontodon caucasicus, commonly known as the Caucasian dandelion, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads made up of numerous small florets. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with basal leaves that are linear to lanceolate in shape. Its flowers are yellow, with a distinctive central disc surrounded by ray florets, and it produces a capsule-like fruit that disperses seeds by wind. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky habitats.
